_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  

Introduction

The City of Sunnyvale's Water Pollution Control Plant (Plant) uses chemicals such as chlorine and sulfur dioxide in the disinfection process for treated wastewater to provide water safe for discharge to the environment and for recycled water for uses such as landscaping irrigation. Storing large quantities of these chemicals can be a hazard if they are not handled properly. The Plant takes its safety obligations for storing and using hazardous chemicals as seriously as providing reliable wastewater treatment. This Executive Summary describes the steps taken to prevent an accidental chemical release, to ensure a safely operated plant, and how the Plant responds to an emergency. To date, the Plant has an excellent record in preventing accidental releases. Please feel free to contact Melody Tovar, Regulatory Programs Division Manager at (408) 730-7808 if you have questions.

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

The Plant implements programs to comply with other accidental release prevention regulations, including California's OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). In the Plant priorities developed by the management team, safety is listed at the number one priority and is not to be compromised for any other issue. All employees are to ensure that both employees and the community are safe at all times from any harm at the Plant. Compliance is the next priority for the Plant and should be planned for as we plan for safety, so that there is never a need to make a choice between the two. Compliance at the Plant means meeting the obligations to various federal, state, and local agencies, as well as protecting the environment and providing an important service to our customers and the citizens of Sunnyvale.

The Plant has written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) established for all plant processes related to PSM and RMP requirements. Writte

n operator training programs for plant processes are in use for current and new operators. The Plant has a Safety Committee consisting of representatives from each section within the Plant that meets on a monthly basis to discuss safety issues and plant operations. Each Plant section has bi-weekly staff safety training meetings to provide training on pertinent operations and plans, with many of the training sessions related to chlorine and sulfur dioxide process safety.

General Facility and Regulated Substances Information

The Plant is located at 1444 Borregas Avenue in Sunnyvale, near the southern tip of the San Francisco Bay. The Plant treats wastewater from the City of Sunnyvale, a small section of the City of Cupertino, and a portion of the Moffett Field Naval Air Station, located in Sunnyvale. The facility has a treatment capacity of 29.5 million gallons per day; average flow is currently 14-16 million gallons per day. Plant processes include preliminary treatment to remove large solids and grit, primary sedimentation to remove settleable solids, oxidation ponds as secondary treatment, biological treatment to nitrify ammonia, flocculation and coagulation for algae removal, filtration to remove suspended solids, disinfection for pathogen reduction, and dechlorination of treated water prior to discharge to render chlorine harmless in the final effluent. The Plant is a 24-hour per day/7-day per week operation. A Senior Operator is always on duty at the facility and will initiate established emergency response procedures in the event of an accidental release or other emergency situation.

The facility currently stores chlorine and sulfur dioxide, which are regulated substances under the RMP and CalARP rules. These are stored in one-ton cylinders and exceed the RMP and Cal ARP threshold quantities. The facility also produces methane gas in its digesters which is used to power influent pump engines and for the co-generation of electricity in two 800 kW genera

. Cylinders are received by Plant personnel from the supplier's truck. Once inside the Plant, all chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are immediately unloaded and placed inside storage buildings where they are safety-secured. The containers are never left outside or unattended. After the cylinders are secured in the storage buildings, an intruder alarm system is activated. The intruder alarm system is active when Plant personnel are not working in the storage buildings.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of each regulated substance. This information was compiled from numerous sources prior to conducting the Process Hazard Analysis. It includes MSDS sheets, chlorine and sulfur dioxide background information, and chlorine and sulfur dioxide reaction chemistry.

Equipment safety information has been compiled on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes, including maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower temperatures, safe upper and lower pressures, and codes and standards used to design build, and operate the processes. The Plant also has procedures in place to update safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis

Plant staff, engineering, and administrative staff conducted an initial, detailed PHAs for the chlorine disinfection system and sulfur dioxide dechlorination system in December 1993. A revalidation of the PHAs was conducted in December 1999 by a team of maintenance, operations, engineering, and administrative staff using the "Hazard and Operability" (HAZOP) method and "What If" methods as per acceptable approach guidance from EPA. Another revalidation using the HAZOP and "What if" methodologies was completed in 2003 and 2006-2007 using a similar team make-up. The most recent

HAZOP revalidation for the chlorine disinfection system was initiated in 2008 (prompted by minor release incidents) and completed in 2010. The most recent sulfur dioxide PHA revalidation was conducted in August 2010. Revalidations were led by a consulting industrial safety professional who was knowledgeable about the types of processes being used and a team of operations and maintenance staff from the Plant participated.

A list of actions and suggested improvements from the most recent PHAs was prepared and all but two actions were completed or addressed by May 2011.  The two remaining items pertaining to the chlorine disinfection system (a change to an inspection and cleaning frequency and the development of an SOP to formalize an existing practice) were completed in June 2012.  Most of the items related to completing and refining the upgrades previously made to the chlorinators.  The Plant is now planning for the impending decommissioning of both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems as described further in the Planned Changes to Improve Safety section.

Operating Procedures

The Plant maintains current, accurate, written operating procedures that include clear instruction for the operation of chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. Operating procedures are incorporated into operation and maintenance training programs. Step-by-step written operating instructions were developed for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems that include procedures for process start up, shutdown, and normal, alternate, and emergency operations. The Plant Safety Committee and Senior Operations Staff review and update procedures, as needed. Also, procedures are developed and put in place whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely. Operating procedures are developed or provided and put in place prior to any new relevant process equipment coming on-line or the start-up for a changed process.

Operations and Maintenance Training Program

Each Plant

employee presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes is trained in an overview of the process and detailed, applicable operating and maintenance procedures. The Plant training program provides information to help employees understand the nature and cause of problems arising from operations involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide, and increases awareness of employees with respect to process hazards. The Plant training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, (3) SCBA use and Level A protective gear qualifications (40-hour HAZWOPER class) for Operations Staff, (4) quarterly drills/training related to chlorine and sulfur dioxide safety procedures for Operations Staff, and (5) a detailed review of process and operating procedures and safe work practices.

Training documentation maintained by the Plant includes: (1) the dates of the most recent reviews or revision of the training program; (2) type of training provided; and (3) the type of competency testing or demonstrations used to ensure that staff understand the training.

Contractors

The Plant has procedures and policies in place to ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. Contractors are informed of process hazards, process area access limitation and emergency response procedures so that they may safely complete their work. The Plant sets minimum contractor safety performance requirements to perform work on or around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process areas and equipment, holds contractor safety briefings before allowing contractors near or into the process areas, controls access to process areas, and evaluates contractor performance.

Mechanical Integrity Program

The Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of all facility equipment,

including covered process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could potentially endanger workers, the public, or the environment. We believe that this program is the primary line of defense against a release and addresses equipment testing and inspection, preventive maintenance schedules, and personnel training. The Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:
- Procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment based on instructions and recommendations from manufacturers, equipment vendors, industry codes, and prior operating experience.
- Implementation of the written procedures in performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
-Training of maintenance personnel in procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and
-Procedures specifying training requirements for contract maintenance employees, as well as requiring contractors to use plant developed maintenance procedures for process areas.

Hot Work Permits

The Plant requires employees and contractors to use safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide process areas, as well as other areas around the facility where flammable materials may be used or stored. Employees must follow the requirements of the Welding, Brazing, Soldering, Cutting, and Related Hot Work SOP and a Hot Work Permit must be issued by a department supervisor before any hot work is performed outside of the designated welding booth. Copies of all permits issued for the previous two years are kept on site.

Management of Change and Pre-startup Safety Reviews

The Plant has a process in place to implement changes or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions. This system allows employees to identify and review safety hazards, provide additional safety, process,

or chemical information to existing data, evaluate the proposed change to confirm that it would not compromise system safety, and establish training requirements before implementation. The Plant ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new covered process at the plant or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information. All proposed process changes must be submitted in writing and include all schematics, diagrams, and specifications for review by Operations, Maintenance, and Management groups and the plant-wide Safety Committee before Plant management authorizes proposed changes.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are completed every three years using a team of personnel who are knowledgeable about the RMP/PSM plan and the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. The team includes representatives from Operations, Maintenance, and Management, plus a consulting safety professional. The team evaluates whether the RMP/PSM Plan and its implementation satisfy the requirements of the RMP/CalARP, and PSM, and if the plan is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations reviewed and resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the RMP/PSM Plan are adopted.

Incident Investigation

In addition to its routine industrial accident investigation program, the Plant investigates all incidents involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide that caused or could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment, so that similar accidents can be prevented. The Plant trains employees to identify and report any incident that requires investigation.

An investigation team is assembled to investigate covered process incidents. Results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate processes enhancements are implemented

. Consultant support is sought as needed. Incident investigation report findings are reviewed by affected staff, used to revise operating and maintenance procedures, and submitted to the Operations Manager and Supervisors for inclusion into existing training programs, if warranted, to prevent future incidents. To date, only minor incidents or "near misses" have been investigated, as there have been no significant releases or injuries.

Toxic Gas Ordinance Compliance

The chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage systems include several safety features and are in full compliance with Santa Clara County's stringent Toxic Gas Ordinance, as well as the Toxic Gas Ordinance (TGO) for the City of Sunnyvale (Sunnyvale Municipal Code Section 16.53). Safety provisions include: 
- All process equipment is located within the building, which provides containment. The building is under negative pressure under normal and emergency ventilation conditions.
- A 3,000 cubic feet per minute (cfm) packed-bed scrubber to treat exhausted air if a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide occurs.
- Louvers automatically close upon detection of a leak and the room space is exhausted to the packed-bed scrubber.
- Sulfur dioxide and chlorine storage and use rooms are equipped with smoke detectors, gas leak detectors, and seismic detectors and manually activated panic buttons at the chlorine and sulfur dioxide facility exits.
- Gas leak detectors in each chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and use room are interconnected to the PLC system with a tiered action system that includes automatic shutdown of the building ventilation systems, activation of the scrubber system, activation of chlorine and sulfur dioxide shutoff valves, and activation of the audible and visual alarm system (plant siren) if triggered. Automated dampers are used to direct airflow to the scrubber from the appropriate containment area. A sensor at the scrubber stack exit will provide automatic shutdown of the scrubber in the

event of a detected release above the trigger level.
- Seismic detectors will cause liquid chlorine and sulfur dioxide supply valves to close and annunciate alarms to indicate the shutoff valves have closed in the event of significant seismic activity.
- Manually-activated panic buttons will cause the chlorine and sulfur dioxide supply valves to close and annunciate alarms to indicate the shutoff valves have closed. 
Ancillary chlorine and sulfur dioxide process equipment used for handling chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers includes the following features:
- Containers are equipped with fusible plugs for pressure relief and steel protective housings for the valve area.
- All valves and fittings used on the chlorine system are certified for chlorine use.
- The header system is equipped with a frangible (or "rupture") disk, shut-off valves, and a high-pressure switch.
- The chlorine and sulfur dioxide evaporators are thermostatically controlled
- The chlorine system pressure relief valve is vented through the scrubber
- The facility maintains a Chlorine Institute Emergency "B" Kit for use in responding to a leak from the one-ton cylinders, self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBAs) and appropriate personal protection equipment for use in emergency response situations. The SCBAs are also used by staff and are on "standby" during equipment change out.
- The Plant is enclosed by a fence and the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage areas are equipped with motion sensor alarms to notify operators of unauthorized entry to the buildings. System alarms are monitored at computer stations that give a plant-wide, audible alarm to Operations personnel, which are staffed 24 hours per day, 7 days a week.

Facility maintenance

- The Plant has a comprehensive written mechanical integrity program with an automated tracking and scheduling for the work order and preventive maintenance system.
- The facility has a written Management of Change standard operating procedu

re that is to be used when changes to the process procedures, process chemicals, equipment, or technology may affect the chlorine or sulfur dioxide facilities.
- Items identified for improvement during HAZOP reviews as a part of the Process Hazard Analysis are tracked to ensure their implementation.

Staff training

- Plant Operations staff receive chlorine and sulfur dioxide process and facility safety training five times each year.  Plant Maintenance staff receive chlorine and sulfur dioxide process and facility safety training annually.
- Additional safety training related to plant processes and operations is provided on a biweekly basis. Annual updates regarding chlorine and sulfur dioxide safety plans are provided to all staff as a part of the regular safety program.

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the last five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite and no known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Emergency Response Program

The Plant has established a written emergency response program for employees to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. This program has been coordinated with the City of Sunnyvale - Certified Unified Public Agency (CUPA) emergency response agencies. The program includes emergency response procedures and an evacuation plan specific to chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. Chlorine and sulfur dioxide area Plant operators are trained as first responders. Operator training and response for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes are conducted quarterly. 

Flooding Considered

A flood of the Plant would result in a loss of power to the facility. This would cause a PRV (pressure regulated valve) shut down on the gas systems, the loss of service air, loss of heat, and shut-down of chlorinator and sulfonator systems. All chlorine a

nd sulfur dioxide cylinders are secured, so there is no danger of their movement.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Sunnyvale Water Pollution Control Plant plans to decommission both the SO2 and Cl2 gas systems within the next five years.  In 2012, the Plant converted to the use of sodium bisulfite for dechlorination as part of the disinfection process, eliminating the ongoing use of SO2 at the facility.  As part of a larger infrastructure plan, the Plant will also convert to the use of sodium hypochlorite for disinfection as an alternative to gaseous chlorine.  That project is currently in the planning phase.  When that project is completed, the siting for the sodium bisulfite will also be relocated and sulfur dioxide is planned for use during the transition.  Therefore, even with the conversion to sodium bisulfite, the existing SO2 system currently remains, with maintenance of safety functions and protocols, until a full decommissioning of the SO2/CL2 system is conducted after the new disinfection system is implemented.

The Plant will continue to implement and update its Risk Management Plan components.  In 2013, the Plant plans to revise its Emergency Planning components, including coordination with the Department of Public Safety on emergency protocols.  The Plant will also be conducting a program compliance audit in 2013.
